The 'MÃ©tis' (; ; ) are one of the recognized Aboriginal peoples in Canada. They
trace their descent to mixed First Nations and European heritage. The term was
historically a catch-all describing the offspring of any such union, but within
generations the culture syncretised into what is today a distinct aboriginal
group, with formal recognition equal to that of the Inuit and First Nations.
Mothers were often Cree, Ojibwe, Algonquin, Saulteaux, Menominee, Mi'kmaq or
Maliseet. At one time there was an important distinction between
'French MÃ©tis' born of francophone [[Voyageurs|voyageur]] fathers, and the '[[Anglo-
MÃ©tis]]' or 'Countryborn' descended from English or Scottish fathers. Today
these two cultures have essentially coalesced into one MÃ©tis tradition. [http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/genealogie/022-905.004-
e.html Ethno-Cultural and Aboriginal Groups] Rinella, Steven. 2008.
American Buffalo: In Search of A Lost Icon. NY: Spiegel and Grau. Other
former namesâmany of which are now considered to be offensiveâinclude Bois-
BrÃ»lÃ©s, Mixed-bloods, Half-breeds, Bungi, Black Scots and Jackatars.

The MÃ©tis homeland includes regions scattered across Canada, as well as parts of
the northern United States (specifically Montana, North Dakota, and northwest
Minnesota). Howard, James H. 1965. The Plains-Ojibwa or Bungi: hunters and
warriors of the Northern Prairies with special reference to the Turtle Mountain
band. University of South Dakota Museum Anthropology Papers 1 (Lincoln,
Nebraska: J. and L. Reprint Co., Reprints in Anthropology 7, 1977).
